question.qText: Which of the following statements represents Brueghel’s point of view?

aBtn.aText: The point of view of the artist is that he wanted to realistically portray a scene in a town near where he lived.
Since Brughel has placed himself above the scene, and seems to poke fun at the activities; he probably thinks both Carnival and Lent are foolish and excessive.

question.qText: Which of the following statements represents Brueghel’s point of view?

aBtn.aText: Brueghel condemns the immoral behavior of Carnival and makes fun of the overly pious figure of Lent, so he seems to be saying that no one in the town is behaving in a truly Christian way.
Brueghel’s has a sarcastic point of view because he is an artist.

question.qText: How does the fact that Carnival and Lent do not actually clash reflect Brueghel’s point of view?

aBtn.aText: Brueghel may believe that carnival and lent are both sides of the Catholic faith and therefore irrelevant to the conflict between Protestants and Catholics.
Brueghel may believe that battles over religion are foolish and produce no winner.
